importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Landmark study (LEAP) was published in 2015, shifting pediatric allergy guidelines and leading to early allergen introduction recommendations.
National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases published updated guidelines recommending early peanut introduction for high-risk infants.
The article's publication date reflects current evidence showing long-term effects of the 2015 guideline shift on food allergy prevalence.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 10-year period from 2015 to 2025 is critical for assessing the impact of early allergen introduction on peanut and food allergy rates in the U.S.

keyTakeAways: Early introduction of peanuts (around 4–6 months) reduces the risk of peanut allergy in children.
A 43% reduction in peanut allergy prevalence and a 36% reduction in overall food allergy prevalence have been observed since guideline changes in 2015–2017.
At least 40,000 cases of peanut allergies have been prevented in the U.S. over the past decade.
The change in guidance was prompted by the LEAP study, which found that early exposure to peanuts reduced allergy development.
The revised guidelines are now reflected in major health documents like the Dietary Guidelines for Americans.

Despite positive trends, challenges remain, including incomplete adoption by families due to fear of cross-exposure and limitations in data collection (e.g., reliance on diagnostic codes, not actual eating habits).

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study published in the journal Pediatrics shows that reversing the long-standing advice of avoiding peanuts in infants has significantly reduced food allergy rates in the U.S. Since 2015, when a landmark study (LEAP) found that early exposure to peanuts reduces allergy risk, U.S. health guidelines have shifted to recommend introducing peanuts to high-risk infants as early as 4 to 6 months. This change has led to a 43% reduction in peanut allergy prevalence and a 36% reduction in overall food allergy rates. Researchers estimate that over 40,000 cases of peanut allergy have been prevented in the past decade. The shift is reflected in national guidelines such as the Dietary Guidelines for Americans and recommendations from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. Despite positive outcomes, challenges remain, including incomplete family adherence due to fear of cross-reactivity and limitations in data collection, such as reliance on diagnostic codes instead of actual dietary habits. Experts like Dr. Corinne Keet remain cautious, calling for more validation and long-term data, but agree that the overall trend is a major public health improvement.
title: Reversing peanut advice prevented tens of thousands of allergy cases, researchers say
